GENERAL INTRODUCTION TO THE EPODES.

‘LIBER EPODON,’ ‘Liber Vtus qui Epodon inscribitur‚' are the titles by which this Book is headed in MSS, and cited by the grammatical and metrical writers of the 4th and 5th cen- turies‚ Marius Victorinus, Diomedes, Fortunatianus. The separate poems are called Odae. The word Epode (ἐπῳδός) was a recognized metrical term for the shorter verse of a couplet, which is as it were the echo (ἐπᾴδεται, ‘accinitur') of ‘a the longer one, and then συνεκδοχικῶς for the metre or poem ἵ (more properly ‘carmen epodicum') in which such a sequence occurred ¹. Elegiac verses are thus admitted as Epodic by Vic- torinus (p. 2300), but in common use the term was appropriated to the couplet metres of Archilochus and their Horatian imi- tations. It may be noticed that such metres are not peculiar to the so-called ‘Epodes.' Two of the couplets known specially by Archilochus' name occur only in the Odes (Ι. 4, and 4. 7); the latter is the one example of an ‘Epodus' quoted from Horace by Terentianus Maurus.
